Click the "+" symbol in the upper right corner to add a new emotion to the list. Once added, it will appear as a button on the list for easy access. Use the "–" symbol to delete items from the list that are no longer being used. 


	If the emotion you want to log is on your list, click it to create a log entry. A new list will appear for you to populate with your common triggers


	Click “Review” to switch to Daily Review mode. This shows a timeline of all your emotions throughout the day. To see past reviews, swipe left to go back in time one day, and right to go forward.
1. Create your own emotions and triggers

\tInstead of using a pre-generated list of emotions or triggers, you are encouraged to look within and discover what you feel for yourself, instead relying on cliche emotional labels. Every emotion or trigger you add to the lists is saved for future use. As human beings, we tend to exhibit habitual repetitive emotional patterns. By maintaining a saved list of individually generated emotions and triggers, MoodMapper can aid us in discovering and understanding our habitual patterns
2. Keep refining your emotion and trigger lists

\tEmotional awareness is not an easy task, but with practice we are bound to improve at it. As your emotional discernment grows, be willing to clean up your lists of unused or irrelevant items in order to see more clearly the repeating patterns. The idea is not to collect as many emotions as possible, but to understand the patterns that drive us at a deep level.
3. Learn to recognize emotions by their \"flavor\"

\tEach emotion you add to the list should have its own distinct \"flavor\". Often these "flavors" don\'t have a convenient label from everyday language that captures all of their nuance. That is another reason for creating our own list of emotions instead of using ready-made lists. The idea is to find a unique label for each distinct flavor of emotion you recognize. Gradually these emotions that once seemed vague and unrecognizable, will become clear and familiar, just as unfamiliar vocabulary gradually becomes known through repeated encounters, even without looking it up.
